What Is The Array of Things?

What if a light pole told you to watch out for an icy patch of sidewalk ahead? What if an app told you the most populated route for a late-night walk to the El station by yourself? What if you could get weather and air quality information block-by-block, instead of city-by-city?

The Array of Things (AoT) is a network of interactive, modular sensor boxes around Chicago to collect real-time data on the city’s environment, infrastructure, and activity for research and public use.

What is the Goal of The Array of Things?

  • To better understand the natural and built environment of the city and its impact on livability with respect to climate, air quality, noise, and other factors, effectively creating a "fitness tracker" for Chicago.
  • To make this data available to citizens, software developers, scientists, and policymakers so that all can work together to make cities healthier, more livable and more efficient.
  • To enable research, development, prototyping and demonstration of new capabilities that require hardware and software technologies to be “embedded” in the built infrastructure.
  • To enable new training and education opportunities in science and technology, particularly related to cities.

AoT intends to operate as a “national instrument” for urban science and technology research, ranging from technology to social sciences and education.

What Data is Collected?

Sensors are aimed primarily at understanding atmosphere, air quality, and environmental factors: temperature, humidity, light, CO, NO2, vibration.

Three sensors are affected by human activity. A sound sensor will collect data on ambient volume. An infared camera, pointed at nearby sidewalk and road surfaces, collects temperature information. A wireless LAN can count the number of Bluetooth- or WiFi-enabled devices in the vicinity, as a proxy for pedestrian traffic. The sensors do not record any identifying information from devices.

What Can Be Done With This Data?

Potential applications of data collected by the Array of Things include:

  • Monitor air quality and determine the healthiest and unhealthiest walking paths and times through the city
  • Detect temperature of sidewalks and roads to guide more targeted and efficient salting in winter
  • Measure and record micro-climate in different areas of the city
  • Observe which areas of the city are heavily populated to suggest safe routes
  • Detect heavy traffic through sound and vibration

We hope that collaboration with the community will lead to further valuable applications.

What Data Will Be Available?

All data will published with multiple updates per minute, openly and at no cost, following the City of Chicago's established policy that data about the city is not monetized but is provided as a public utility.

In addition, all software, hardware, parts, and specifications will also be published as open source, to encourage participation and oversight from the developer community and public.

Who is the Array of Things team?

The Array of Things project is led by researchers from the Urban Center for Computation and Data, the Computation Institute, Argonne National Laboratory, the University of Chicago, and the City of Chicago. The exterior face of the sensor nodes was designed by Douglas Pancoast and Satya Mark Basu of the School of the Art Institute of Chicago

Additional institutions involved in the project include the University of Illinois at Chicago, Northern Illinois University, Notre Dame University, Arizona State University, the Institute for Advanced Architecture of Catalonia, the University of Strathclyde, the Illinois Institute of Technology, and Northwestern University. Corporate collaborators include Cisco, Schneider Electric, Intel, Microsoft Research, and Zebra Technologies
